definition.p: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers. A matrix with m rows and n columns is called an m \times n matrix.
A matrix with the same number of rows and columns is called a square matrix.

statement.p:
For the given matrix, answer the following questions: A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 2 & 5 \\ 2 & -6 & 0 & 1 \\ 3 & -1 & 4 & 7 \end{bmatrix}
What are the dimensions of A?
What is the third column of A?
What is the second row of A?
What is the element a_{23}?
What is the element a_{32}?

definition.p: Let A be an m\times k matrix, and let B be a k\times n matrix. Then the product AB = \begin{bmatrix}c_{ij} \end{bmatrix} is defined by: c_{ij} = a_{i1}\cdot b_{1j} + a_{i2}\cdot b_{2j} + \dots + a_{ik}\cdot b_{kj}

statement.p: Find AB if A = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -3 \\ 3 & -1 \\ 0 & -2 \\ -1 & 5 \end{bmatrix} and B = \begin{bmatrix} -1 & 3 & 2 & -2 \\ 0 & -1 & 4 & -3 \end{bmatrix}

definition.p: The identity matrix of order n is the n \times n matrix: I_n = \begin{bmatrix} \delta_{ij} \end{bmatrix} \text{ where } \delta_{ij} = \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} 1 & i = j \\ 0 & i \not= j \end{array} \right.
I'll refer to this as the n\times n identity matrix, but to be clear, an identity matrix is always square.

note.p: If A is an m \times n matrix, then: A I_n = I_m A = A

definition.p: If A is a square, n\times n matrix, we define A^r = A A A \dots A, the product of A with itself r times. Further, A^0 = I_n.

statement.p: Let A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}. Find a formula for A^n, n\in \mathbb{Z}^+

definition.p: If A and B are square, n \times n matrices such that AB = BA = I_n, then B is called the inverse of A, and A is said to be invertible. We write B = A^{-1} to denote the inverse matrix.

ol.li: Using the formula in homework, find A^{-1}
Using the matrices above and matrix multiplication, show that A^3 and (A^{-1})^3 are inverses.

definition.p: Let A be an m \times n matrix. We define the transpose of A, denoted A^t to be the n\times m matrix obtained by interchanging the rows and columns of A.
A square matrix is called symmetric if A = A^t.
A binary matrix (or Boolean matrix) is one for which all of its entries are either 0 or 1.

Let A = \begin{bmatrix} a_{ij} \end{bmatrix} and B = \begin{bmatrix} b_{ij} \end{bmatrix} be two m\times n binary matrices. We define:
The join of A and B, denoted A \lor B, to be the m \times n matrix whose ijth entry is a_{ij} \lor b_{ij}.
The meet of A and B, denoted A \land B, to be the m \times n matrix whose ijth entry is a_{ij} \land b_{ij}.

Let A be an m\times k matrix, and let B be a k\times n matrix. Then the Boolean product A\odot B = \begin{bmatrix}c_{ij} \end{bmatrix} is defined by: c_{ij} = a_{i1}\land b_{1j} \lor a_{i2}\land b_{2j} \lor \dots \lor a_{ik}\land b_{kj}
If A is a square, n\times n binary matrix, we define A^{[r]} = A\odot A\odot A\odot \dots \odot A, the Boolean product of A with itself r times. Further, A^{[0]} = I_n.

subsection.title: Doing Matrix Arithmetic with SageMath
subsection.p: We can check our work using Sage, which will let us do really large matrix operations.

statement.p:
First, let's see how to write a matrix in Sage. The following code represents the matrix \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ 5 & 2\end{bmatrix} and then displays it:
A = matrix([[3, 1], [5,2]]); A
[3 1] [5 2]

Now let's use Sage to multiply matrices:
A = matrix([[3, 1], [5,2], [1, 1]]); B = matrix([[1, 2, 0], [4,0, 1]]); A*B
[ 7 6 1] [13 10 2] [ 5 2 1]

ul.li: First, I see ----> 3 A*B in error, the arrow telling us what line had the error. The error happened when I was multiplying.

li.p:
Then, scrolling to the end, we see:
TypeError: unsupported operand parent(s) for *: 'Full MatrixSpace of 3 by 3 dense matrices over Integer Ring' and 'Full MatrixSpace of 2 by 3 dense matrices over Integer Ring'
That's a lot information, but look what we have:
Unsupported operand parent(s) for * tells us that we have a problem with our multiplication.
My eyes caught ... 3 by 3 ... 2 by 3... which tells me I'm trying to multiply incompatible matrices.

statement.p:
Let A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 4 \\ -3 & 2 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} and let B = \begin{bmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}, find:
A + B
B - A
AB
A^t
B^t
B^t A^t
(AB)^t
You can check your work with Sage. If you want to find the transpose of a matrix named A, you type A.transpose(). But remember, you can't use the computer or a fancy calculator on the test.
